body:
Ever found yourself in the midst of a Git nightmare, like accidentally pushing your work-in-progress branch straight to production? It happens to the best of us.

But mastering Git isn't just about memorizing commands and executing them robotically. It's about understanding the underlying principles, developing best practices, and learning from both successes and failures. It's about transforming Git from a tool you use to a skill you wield with confidence.

Whether you're a coding newbie just starting to explore version control or a seasoned developer looking to refine your Git skills, this tutorial is the perfect git roadmap for you.

## What to expect:

**Foundation Building:** Lay the groundwork for Git control with essential concepts and techniques, from repositories and branches to commits and merges.

**Command Chronicles:** Explore vital Git commands such as `git help` and `git pull` to equip yourself with the skills and confidence needed to navigate Git effectively.

lessons.body:
The first time that I used Git on a team I made a huge mistake.

I took the work-in-progress branch that I was developing and I force pushed it to production.

The lead on the team spent the whole day kind of untangling the mess I'd made and reconstructing the history from all the various distributed branches that everyone else had.

This embarrassing experience led me to commit to getting really good with Git.

Over the last 14 years since that incident, I've become the person who offers assistance and helps people when they've made a mess of their Git history.

This tutorial will lay the foundation for success in Git. But don't be fooled; it's not just for beginners. Even after my 15+ years of experience with Git, I learned some things while doing the research for these lessons.

No matter where you're at in your Git journey, I believe there's something here for you.

lessons.title: Git Help Options
lessons.description: Improve your daily Git usage by learning essential help commands, including tutorials and subcommand instructions for a smoother workflow.
lessons.body:
The most important Git command that you can learn is `git help`.

Running `git help` with no options will give you a great summary of the `git` command along with several sections for common commands:

```bash
usage: git [-v | --version] [-h | --help] [-C <path>] [-c <name>=<value>]
           [--exec-path[=<path>]] [--html-path] [--man-path] [--info-path]
           [-p | --paginate | -P | --no-pager] [--no-replace-objects] [--bare]
           [--git-dir=<path>] [--work-tree=<path>] [--namespace=<name>]
           [--super-prefix=<path>] [--config-env=<name>=<envvar>]
           <command> [<args>]

These are common Git commands used in various situations:

start a working area (see also: git help tutorial)
   clone     Clone a repository into a new directory
   init      Create an empty Git repository or reinitialize an existing one

...
```

At the bottom of the help summary, you'll see two additional commands that are extremely helpful: `git help -a` and `git help -g`:

```tsx
'git help -a' and 'git help -g' list available subcommands and some concept guides.
```

When running `git help -g` you'll get a list of tutorials. For example, `everyday` is a set of commands for everyday Git.

If you run `git help -a`, you'll get a list of all the subcommands.

To get instructions for using for a specific subcommand, you can run `git help subcommand`, for example: `git help init`.

To search for a subcommand, type `/subcommand` and hit enter. Use `shift + N` to go back and `N` to go forward. Press `Q` to quit.

lessons.description: Learn how to use the git init command to create and initialize new git repositories, and explore the hidden .git directory.
lessons.body:
`git init` is the command used to create a new git repository. To initialize a repository in a new directory, provide an optional path:

```bash
git init my-git-notes
```

Move into the directory with `cd my-git-notes`, then run `ls` and see that the directory appears empty.

However, running `ls -a` reveals that there is a hidden `.git` directory:

```bash
$~/my-git-notes> ls -a

.git
```

You can use Use `ls .git` to list the contents of the `.git` directory:

![image terminal](https://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1709589012/tutorials/git-foundations/Screenshot_2024-03-04_at_3.44.43_PM.png)

This `.git` directory with those nested folders and files is what makes this otherwise normal system directory into a git repository.

For more `git init` options and information, type `git help init`.

lessons.description: Learn how to use git status command to view repository information, track and commit changes, and understand the importance of the .git directory.
lessons.body:
`git status` is a command you'll use all the time when working with Git repositories.

This command will show the current branch you're on, and your commit history.

Since our repository is new, there isn't much to see:

```
$ git status

On branch main
No commits yet
nothing to commit (create/copy files and use "git add" to track)
```

This functionality is powered by the hidden `.git` directory in our repository. But what happens if we remove that directory?

```
$ rm -vrf .git
```

Now, when we run `git status`, it no longer works because this is no longer a repository, it's just a folder.

```tsx
$ git status

fatal: not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git
```

To get back to where we were, run `git init` again inside the directory:

```bash
git init
```

lessons.body:
When we ran `git status` inside of our repository in our previous lesson , we were told that there is nothing to commit, and that we should make files and add them. So let's do that!

## Create Files with `echo`

The `echo` command can be used to write text into new files.

The following commands will create new files for `git-help.txt`, `git-init.txt`, and `git-status.txt`:

```markdown
echo "#git-help" > git-help.txt
echo "#git-init" > git-init.txt
echo "#git-status" > git-status.txt
```

Running `ls` will show us the files have been created.

## Check the File Status

Running `git status` shows that there are untracked files:

```markdown
$ git status

On branch main
No commits yet
Untracked files:
(use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
git-help.txt
git-init.txt
git-status.txt
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
```

In order to track the files, we first need to add them.

## Add Files

We can add the files with the `git add` command along with a filename.

Let's add `git-help.txt` first:

```
git add githelp.txt
```

Running `git status` again, we have an additional section called "changes to be committed.":

```tsx
$ git status

On branch main
No commits yet
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage)
        new file:   git-help.txt

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
        git-init.txt
        git-status.txt
```

Note that the `git-help.txt` changes aren't committed yet but staged for commit.

## Stage the Rest of the Files

The remaining files can be individually with `git add`.

However, using the shortcut `git add .` will add everything that hasn't been added to the index.

After adding the rest of the files, running `git status` one last time will show that everything has been moved into our index and staged for commit.

lessons.description: Learn how to manage the staging area before creating a commit by utilizing the git reset command to exclude files and changes.
lessons.body:
Before we create a commit, we want to make sure that only files and changes that we intend to include are in the index or staged area.

To remove a file from the commit, you can use the `git reset` command with the filename:

```markdown
git reset git-status.txt
```

After running the command, you can use `git status` again to verify that the file has been removed from the staged area.

```tsx
$ git status

No commits yet

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage)
        new file:   git-help.txt
        new file:   git-init.txt

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
        git-status.txt
```

Like before, `get reset .` will remove all files from the staged area. This allows you to review and stage the intended files before committing.

Before you can commit anything, you need to add some git configuration. Assuming you're not on a shared machine, you can add this globally.

You'll need to add a username and a user email address that you'd like to show up in your commits.

Use the `config` command with the `--global` flag to set your username and email with these commands:

```markdown
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "youremail@address.com"
```

At any time, you can see your git config using the list flag:

```markdown
git config --list
```

This command will display the two options you provided, alongside some system defaults. With a user and email, you're now ready to sign your commits.

lessons.description: Learn how to manage your code with git by committing changes, staging files, and checking the status of your working tree.
lessons.body:
The `git commit` command is used to make a commit. Commits require a message, which is added with the `-m` flag.

It's a good practice to use present tense commit messages:

```
git commit -m "Add help, init, and status notes"
```

After the `commit` command finishes, it will show the branch, its abbreviated commit SHA, and the message that we wrote:

```
$ git commit -m "Add help, init, and status notes"

[main (root-commit) 1e3b9b0] Add help, init, and status notes
 3 files changed, 3 insertions(+)
 create mode 100644 git-help.txt
 create mode 100644 git-init.txt
 create mode 100644 git-status.txt
```

Note that if no files are staged to be committed, the `commit` command will return the status output instead of actually making a commit.

After a successful commit, running `git status` again will report that there's nothing to commit and we have a clean working tree:

```
$ git status

On branch main
nothing to commit, working tree clean
```

lessons.description: Discover how to inspect and navigate through git commit history using `git show` and various arguments, such as commit SHA and aliases.
lessons.body:
`git show` is a command that allows you to inspect your commits. When used without any arguments, it will display the latest commit, including the full diff that the commit composes:

```markdown
$ git show

commit 1e3b9b0061712908132409ssdf234 (HEAD -> main)
Author: Your Name <youremail@address.com>
Date: Mon Jan 1 00:00:00 2021 -0400

    Add help, init, and status notes

diff --git a/git-help.txt b/git-help.txt
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..e69de29
--- /dev/null
+++ b/git-help.txt
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+#git-help
diff --git a/git-init.txt b/git-init.txt
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..23b0b9e
```

Pressing `q` on your keyboard will exit this view.

You can also be explicit with `git show` by using the commit SHA. You can either use the full shaw or the abbreviated six-character version:

```markdown
git show 1e3b9b
```

If the commit you want to inspect is at the head of the main branch, you can use the `HEAD` alias instead of the commit SHA:

```markdown
git show HEAD
```

These commands will display the same information as in the example above.

lessons.body:
Before we learn a new command, let's work through a quick exercise to practice the git subcommands we've covered so far.

## Check `git status`

Running `git status` shows that we have several files that are not yet staged for commit:

```markdown
$ git status

On branch main
Untracked files:
(use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
git-add.txt
git-commit.txt
git-config.txt
git-log.txt
git-reset.txt
git-show.txt
```

## Add and Commit

Let's add the `git-add.txt` and `git-reset.txt` files:

```markdown
git add git-add.txt git-reset.txt
```

Then we'll commit them and add a message:

```markdown
git commit -m "Add stagingi subcommand notes"
```

Notice we made a typo in the commit message!

## Amend a Commit Message

We can fix the most recent commit message with `git commit --amend`:

```markdown
git commit --amend
```

This will open the terminal text editor (usually Vim) to edit the message:

In Vim, use the arrow keys to navigate to the incorrect character, press `x` to delete it, and then type `:wq` to save and quit.

If there was more than a single character that needs fixed, you could use `i` to enter Vim's insert mode and fix the message. Hit `escape` to exit insert mode and type `:wq` to save and quit.

## See Commits with `git show`

Back in the terminal, run `git show` to see the last commit and verify that the message is fixed.

To check previous commits, use `git show head^` will show us the commit before last. The `^` is a relative reference added to `head` which says we want the previous commit:

```markdown
git show head^
```

In this case, we'll see the commit from earlier when we added the `git-help.txt`, `git-init.txt`, and `git-status.txt` files.

Pressing `q` will exit the commit view.

## Stage and Commit Remaining Files

Now, let's stage the remaining files with `git add .`:

```markdown
$ git add .

On branch main
Changes to be committed:
(use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
new file: git-commit.txt
new file: git-config.txt
new file: git-log.txt
new file: git-show.txt
```

Because the `git-config.txt` file operates on the git configuration and not on commits, we want to keep this file separate from the other commands.

## Unstage a File

To unstage the `git-config.txt` file, use `git reset`:

```markdown
git reset git-config.txt
```

Alternatively, you could unstage all files with `git reset .` then add back what you need to commit.

We've successfully staged, committed, fixed a commit message, and unstaged a file using various git subcommands, but we had to

## Use String Globs as Wildcards

If you're tired of typing the full file name, you can use a string glob to identify a file.

For example, we could target `get-config.txt` with the following:

```markdown
git add '_con_'
```

Since the `con` substring is unique to the `git-config.txt` file, it will be the only one added.

Once the file is added, we can commit the changes:

```markdown
git commit -m "Add username and email config"
```

## Add Files in Interactive Mode

To add the remaining files, let's use `git add` in interactive mode:

```markdown
git add -i
```

This mode allows us to interact with the staging area without having to prefix all of our commands with `git`:

![git interactive screenshot](https://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1709677836/tutorials/git-foundations/Screenshot_2024-03-05_at_4.14.07_PM.png)

In the "What now?" space, type the letter of the corresponding command you want to use.

We want to use "add untracked", so we'll enter `a`.

Now, you'll see the remaining untracked files. Use the numbers to select the file.

![files added in interactive mode](https://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1709677837/tutorials/git-foundations/Screenshot_2024-03-05_at_4.16.07_PM.png)

Once you're done, hit enter again to go back to the "What now?" prompt.

## Check the Status in Interactive Mode

To check the status, type `s` at the prompt. It will show that the three files are now staged:

```markdown
What now> s
staged unstaged path
1: +1/-0 nothing git-commit.txt
2: +1/-0 nothing git-log.txt
3: +1/-0 nothing git-show.txt
```

You can revert any changes by inputting `r` at the prompt if needed.

If everything looks good, hit enter to get out of that and use `q` to quit the interactive mode.

## Check `git status` and Commit

After exiting interactive mode, `git status` will show everything that we committed with `git add` interactive mode. Go ahead and commit the changes with `git commit -m "Add commit subcommands"`.

Now you've learned how to edit commit messages, use string globs to select files, and use git in interactive mode. You're ready to move on to the next command.

lessons.body:
The `git log` command shows a list of commits in your repository.

By default, the output is verbose and shows detailed information about each commit:

![Git log default view](https://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1709678379/tutorials/git-foundations/Screenshot_2024-03-05_at_4.33.18_PM.png)

Using the `--oneline` flag will give a more concise view of the commit history. This will display just the most relevant information for each commit, including the first 7 characters of each SHA and its message:

```bash
git log --oneline
```

![Git log one line view](https://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1709678384/tutorials/git-foundations/Screenshot_2024-03-05_at_4.34.21_PM.png)

If you like this concise format and want to save it as the default setting, you can configure Git to always use the `oneline` format by setting the `format.pretty` option in your `git config`:

```bash
git config format.pretty oneline
```

Interestingly, adding the `online` option to the config results in the full SHA being shown in the log output. To ensure the abbreviated SHA is used, set the `log.abbrevCommit` option to `true`:

```bash
git config log.abbrevCommit true
```

With these configuration updates, `git log` will display nice, concise log messages.

You can inspect your Git configuration with the `git config --list` command to see which options are being applied.

Git repositories are designed to be distributed, so let's share `my-git-notes` online.

## Sharing a Repository on GitHub

When you create a new repository on GitHub, it will provide instructions on how to start with your remote repository. Because we already have a repository, we're going to use the "push an existing repository from the command line" instructions:

```bash
git remote add origin git@github.com:username/my-git-notes.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main
```

Let's read through those commands:

1. `git remote add origin`: Origin is how we refer to our remote repository locally. You could choose a different name, but origin is pretty conventional. The origin repository lives at the address you use in your command, in this case, it lives at `https://github.com/chantastic/my-git-notes.git`

2. `git branch -M main`: This command changes the primary branch to main.

3. `git push -u origin main`: This command ensures that our local branch and origin branch share the same relative name `main`.

After running the commands, we'll see the status of what's being pushed up to the remote repository, and a confirmation that this new remote branch has been added and is being tracked:

![git push output](https://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1709679797/tutorials/git-foundations/Screenshot_2024-03-05_at_4.57.31_PM.png)

Refreshing the GitHub repo page in the browser will confirm the files made are now available.

lessons.description: Learn how to create, switch, and merge branches in Git, and see how to sync them with your remote repository in GitHub for effective collaboration.
lessons.body:
The `git switch` command is used to to create and switch branches.

Running `git switch` without any arguments will show that we don't have any branches to switch to:

```tsx
$ git switch

fatal: missing branch or commit argument
```

We can create and switch to a branch in a single command with the `-c` option followed by the branch name.

```markdown
git switch -c my-branch
```

After switching to the new branch, running `git log` will show us where the branch diverges:

```tsx
$ git log

617f42f (HEAD -> my-branch, origin/main, main) Add pull note
...
```

Let's do a couple of things on this branch.

## Run `git push`

Running `git push` will push the branch up to the remote repository.

In this case we get an error that tells us we need to set up an origin branch that's connected to this local branch:

```tsx
$ git push

fatal: The current branch my-branch has no upstream branch.
To push the current branch and set the remote as upstream, use

    git push --set-upstream origin my-branch

To have this happen automatically for branches without a tracking upstream, see 'push.autoSetupRemote' in 'git help config'.
```

We can add that configuration with the following command:

```markdown
git config push.autoSetupRemote true
```

Now when we run `git push` again, it will automatically configure the remote tracking branch for us using the same name.

Over in GitHub, our remote repository, hit refresh and see that in addition to our main branch, we now have a `my-branch` as well.

## Add and Commit a New File

Let's add a file on `my-branch`:

```markdown
echo "#git-branch" > git-branch.txt
git add .
git commit -m "Add branch note"
```

Running `git status` shows we are ahead of our origin, which we can fix by running `git push`.

The GitHub page will reload to show that changes were pushed to `my-branch`, but let's run `git log` locally to see what's going on:

```markdown
$ git log

24ed6c9 (HEAD -> my-branch, origin/my-branch) Add branch note
617f42f (origin/main, main) Add pull note
```

The output shows that `my-branch` and `origin/my-branch` are in sync with one another, but both are now ahead of the `main` and `origin/main` branches.

To switch back to the main branch and merge everything from `my-branch` back into the main branch, use the following commands:

```markdown
git switch main
git merge my-branch
```

Now running `git log` will show that the `main` branch is now in sync with `origin/my-branch` and `my-branch`:

```markdown
$ git log

24ed6c9 (HEAD -> main, origin/my-branch, my-branch) Add branch note
```

Artificial intelligence has taken the web development world by storm.
While I don't believe AI will replace our jobs completely, it will help someone to take the job of anyone who doesn't know how to use an AI assistant effectively.

This is why I've put together this video tutorial series showcasing how I incorporate AI assistants in my day-to-day work as a web developer.

## Understanding the AI Mindset

It's important to have a good mindset around AI assistants.

You shouldn't perceive AI assistants as the main coders (yet!). Instead, think of them as useful aids in your programming tasks.

The realm of AI evolves at a rapid pace; by the time you view these videos, there could be more advanced AI tools.

But the focus of these videos is to help you develop a mindset that is universally applicable to any AI tool you use.

While AI tools continue to improve, it's essential to learn how to make the most of these tools efficiently today.

## The AI Tools I Use

Throughout this series, I will be predominantly using [ChatGPT](https://chat.openai.com) along with [GitHub Copilot](https://github.com/features/copilot). Both are paid platforms and are definitely worth the investment, though they do both have free tiers.

Alternative tools include: [Cody by Sourcegraph](https://sourcegraph.com/cody) and [Tabnine](https://www.tabnine.com/).

There are plenty more tools out there, and the intention of this series is not to get into specific tools, but rather to shed light on a fundamental approach to utilizing any AI assistant.

## Maximizing Your AI Assistant

Think of AI assistants as force multipliers they amplify your efforts but don't work without input.

If you think about it, you're the one who wields the hammer and drives the nail; the hammer doesn't operate on its own.

Understanding how to efficiently use these AI tools can greatly enhance your web development skills, and I'm eager to show you how I do it.

When working with AI assistants, the more they know about you, the better.

You have preferences for how you format code, the tools you use, and more. For example, if you're a JavaScript developer, you don't want to ask your AI assistant how to parse JSON and have it give you some Python code. The more contextual information you can provide your AI assistant, the less specific you have to be in your prompt.

The more contextual information your AI assistant has about you, the more succinct your prompts can be.

## Custom Instructions in ChatGPT

You can personalize ChatGPT by using the Custom Instructions feature.

This section allows you to share specifics about your interests, preferred tools, and even details like your prettier config.

There is also the option for providing guidance on how you want the assistant to respond. I prefer a terse, more casual dialogue, and if the assistant needs to address me, it should use my name:

![Custom Instructions in ChatGPT](https://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1707173021/tutorials/ai/10_00-59920-about-yourself-and-the-things-that-youre-interested-in-i-have-like-the-tools-that-im-usi.png)

I continually refine my custom instructions to ChatGPT. Each interaction provides an opportunity to adjust the instructions, helping the assistant avoid undesired actions in the future without me having to explicitly instruct it every time.

## The Value of Customization

Spending time customizing your AI assistant can significantly enhance its usefulness.

Providing context and instructions fine-tuned to your preferences can lead to more improved and personalized responses, so don't hesitate to make it yours!

lessons.body:
Having a conversation with ChatGPT is a great way to explore unfamiliar topics. It can help you get started on a new project or provide a starting point for further research.

## A Real-World Example

In the Epic Workshops, a custom web application is used that embeds videos from Mux.

One day, a workshop participant asked if it was possible to display the duration of the videos on the user interface, so that they would not have to start the video to see its length. I wasn't quite sure how to go about this, as I was not well-versed with the Mux API.

So, I turned to ChatGPT with my question, "I'm using Mux for video hosting. How do I get the length of the Mux video with the Mux playback ID?"

In response, ChatGPT advised me that I would need to get an access token and fetch the video details using a specific endpoint. From there, I could extract the video duration from the response. It even provided an example for me.

That immediate response from ChatGPT provided a path to follow and gave me a sense that what I needed to do was, in fact, possible. It provided details on the API endpoint I needed to hit, which allowed me to start prototyping in my editor.

## Adapting the Solution

The response contained a minor issue- it included the use of `node-fetch`. I prefer not to use that library since `fetch` is now built into Node, but that was a minor detail and easy to work around. The essential part was understanding how to set up the authorization, which was clearly explained.

However, there was another wrinkle for the workshop app.

I couldn't use my token secret since the app runs locally on users' machines, so I would need a proxy in order to use a secret.

I asked ChatGPT again if there was a workaround for using a Mux secret. ChatGPT responded, explaining that avoiding the use of a Mux secret wouldn't be possible due to security reasons.

Although it wasn't the answer I hoped for, it was still extremely helpful. It gave me a clearer overview of the constraints I was working under.

## Start with AI

Often, when we face a technical question, our first instinct might be to Google the answer. However, in my experience an AI assistant like ChatGPT could be a quicker and more efficient solution.

There are times when the AI assistant might not have the answer. But more often than not, it provides useful information to base further exploration on.

ChatGPT helps in understanding the problem space and in finding a starting point to begin implementation. However, always remember to verify such information against official documentation as software and APIs can change.

lessons.body:
Using AI assistants like GitHub Copilot can be a game-changer when it comes to writing tests for your code.

For this example, we will use GitHub Copilot to help us write tests for the `epicweb/invariant` utility while utilizing Node's built-in test runner.

Here's a step-by-step guide on how to use your AI assistant effectively:

### 1. Provide Context

When you go to write tests, keep the relevant files open.
AI assistants like GitHub Copilot can use your project's files as part of its context for code generation. Different AI assistants may have their own ways of including files or even a whole project in context, so it's important to determine the mechanism of your specific AI assistant.

### 2. Write Conversational Prompts

When asking your AI assistant to generate code or tests, start by using more vague, conversational prompts.

For example:

```markdown
Please write a test for the invariant utility.
```

Once you see the response, you can edit the prompt to be more specific depending on the output.

In the case of the `invariant` utility, the generated output used keywords like `describe` and `expect` which are typical for testing utilities but not for Node's built-in test runner.

### 3. Make Your Prompt More Specific

If the generated output isn't what you're looking for, make your prompts more specific. This helps the AI assistant understand what you need, leading to improved output. For example:

```markdown
Please write a test for invariant using the built-in testing utilities from Node (like node:assert and node:test).
```

Review the generated code, and edit your prompt accordingly until you get the desired output.

Once your AI assistant has generated a test that passes, break the implementation and check whether the test still passes or fails. This step is essential to ensure that the generated tests are functional and validates that the AI-generated code is working as intended.

### 4. Prompt GitHub Copilot with a Comment

Another option for interacting with GitHub Copilot is to write a comment with an instruction.

For example:

```markdown
// verify the message argument can be a function
```

Copilot will begin to suggest lines of code for autocompletion based on the comment. You can hit `tab` to accept a full line, or `CMD+right arrow` to accept a single word.

### 5. Ask Copilot to Edit Code

After highlighting some code, you can ask Copilot to edit it.

For example, asking Copilot to verify the error message that is thrown.

Copilot will display a diff to show you how edits would change the code. You can then accept or reject the changes.

![Copilot diff for selected code](https://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1707173265/tutorials/ai/71_06-03100-were-going-to-use-the-callback-form-here--and-we-can-say--return-error-message-equals.png)

## Treat Your AI Assistant as a Pairing Partner

No matter which technique you use for interacting with an AI assistant, treat it as if you were pairing with a coworker. Make the interactions conversational and collaborative. This opens up the possibility of creating code and tests at a faster pace with improved accuracy.

lessons.description: Generate realistic test data effortlessly for efficient database seeding with the help of your AI assistant.
lessons.body:
Imagine you need to seed a database with test data that is realistic.

Instead of coming up with each unique item manually, or using 'lorem ipsum' everywhere, your AI assistant can help you generate realistic data.

By writing a comment inside of your database seeding script, GitHub Copilot will be aware of what you want it to do:

```
// create a bunch of notes with  hardcoded ids that do not use lorem ipsum
```

The AI assistant will follow the pattern already present in your code to create more notes, generating unique and realistic content each time for the various fields:

```javascript
create: [
	{
		id: "abc123",
		title: "Fun facts about koalas",
		content:
			"Koalas are marsupials native to Australia. They are known for their adorable appearance and their diet of eucalyptus leaves...",
	},
];
```

Sometimes, the AI doesn't automatically generate the data as expected.

When that happens, you can use the AI's chat feature to request it to generate more of these hard-coded notes:

```
create another three of these fake hard-coded notes
```

The AI might not get the formatting perfect every time, but the clean-up required is worth the time saved from coming up with your own test data.

If you need to generate a lot of data, you could directly open up the AI's chat and ask it to create examples that meet your requirements:

```javascript
create a bunch of examples of notes that have a hard-coded id, title, and content, based on various subjects and serialized as JSON
```

Once the data has been generated, you can then paste it directly into your seed script.

The combination of inline comments and off-to-the-side chat with your AI assistant keeps you going smoothly and conversationally, saving you a ton of time. This is a fantastic way of generating realistic data with the help of your AI assistant.

Animation and interactivity are key to creating engaging user experiences, but they can be intimidating.

There's more to this tutorial than just the code.

Along the way, Simon shares his thought process and design decisions behind each Tailwind class that gets added. You'll learn how to think like a UI designer and develop the intuition for making things look good.

The cards on the DJI site have an effect where the hovered card expands and the other cards shrink:

When we hover, the `hover:grow-[2]` class sets the `flex-grow` to 2, which means that the hovered card will take up twice the space of the other cards:

<li
  key={index}
  class="group relative h-[500px] w-full overflow-hidden rounded-2xl bg-rose-300 flex-1 hover:grow-[2]"
>

<li

The closer you are to the server, the faster your experience will be.

It wasn't long ago that web app developers had to choose a region where they thought the bulk of their users would be located, leaving people on the other side of the world with longer waiting times.

Fortunately, times have changed and it's now possible to deploy an application and have it be distributed worldwide and it's not as tough as it sounds!

This tutorial will show you how to deploy a multi-region Node.js application with a persistent database, ensuring optimal performance no matter where your users are located thanks to Fly.io.

Here are some of the topics you'll tackle along the way:

## Deployment with Fly.io

The first step is to get acquainted with configuring Docker and Fly's CLI tool by deploying the demo Counter app.

After all, you have to have everything working in one region before you make it work in multiple regions!

## Data Persistence and Health Checks

You'll learn how to create persisted volumes to avoid data loss, as well as the steps for setting up health checks and custom endpoints for monitoring the app.

## Automatic Deployment with GitHub Actions

The deployment process is pretty easy thanks to Fly's CLI tool but automating it makes it even easier 

## Creating a Staging Environment

Testing your app safely in a staging environment before it goes live is a great way to ensure a smoother rollout with reduced risk of downtime. This is a huge benefit that comes from a minimal amount of configuration.

## Embrace the Distributed Architecture

Once you understand how the pieces fit together, you'll be ready to deploy the demo application to regions all around the world.  
But it's not just the app itself. Fly.io supports LiteFS, which is used to replicate SQLite databases. This means your database can live on the edge, right beside your application.

Everything you learn about deployment in this tutorial is ready for you to put into action for your own applications.

Ready to fly?

Let's do this!

lessons.body:
Hello everyone! My name is Kent C. Dodds and I'm thrilled that you have decided to join me on this tutorial to learn how to deploy distributed Node.js apps with your data all over the world.

In this tutorial, we'll be deploying our Node.js app and our SQLite database on fly.io.

This has multiple regions all over the world so you can get your data and your app as close to the user as possible.

Let's take a quick look at our demo app before we get started.

The demo app is really simple- it's just a counter that's persisted in the database. This way, we can make sure that deploying migrations and other processes happen correctly.

We can use this to get a good idea of what Fly is capable of, and then you can apply that to more complex applications.

The application is built with the regular `http` module from Node.js, and Prisma is used for migrations. Prisma is the best ORM for JavaScript, TypeScript, and Node that I've experienced!

The application's TypeScript code is basic, and nothing to worry yourself too much about.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815777/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-01-intro.mp4/01-intro_18_01-42600-then-we-just-have-basic-application-code-going-on-here.png)

Deploying distributed apps is actually a pretty complicated thing in general, but Fly makes it really straightforward.

But the way that I'm going to do this tutorial is that you can follow along with me in your own app and then stop at the point where you are able to apply what you've learned.

For example, if you don't need to run your application in multiple regions, you can stop partway through this tutorial.

But if you feel like your application necessitates the complexities of multi-region, then continue to follow along with the extra multi-region stuff. Maybe eventually our tools will get so good that you won't even be able to feel a difference between deploying in a single region and deploying in multiple!

I hope that you enjoy this journey with me and that you can build excellent user experiences with the tools.

See you in the tutorial!

lessons.description: We will deploy to Fly with Docker. A Dockerfile is used to tell Docker the steps to take to run our app.
lessons.body:
Fly has docs for deploying from various places, but we are going to deploy with Docker.

We will build our own Docker file, and then we'll configure Fly to use it.

## Adding a `dockerignore` File

The first thing we will do is create a file that will ensure that none of these files make it into our Docker image.

This `.dockerignore` file will contain pretty much everything that's in the `.gitignore` file. We also want to add a couple of things like the `Dockerfile` that we're about to create, the `.dockerignore` file itself, and the `.git` directory because we don't need all of our git history in there.

Here's what's in the `.dockerignore`:

```markdown
node_modules
.env
/build
/.vscode
prisma/sqlite.db
prisma/sqlite.db-journal
Dockerfile
.dockerignore
.git
```

## Adding the `Dockerfile`

Now it's time to to make our `Dockerfile` itself.

This is a bit of a beast, so I'm actually going to just copy a whole `Dockerfile` for you, then we will make changes as needed.

So I'll kind of walk through what this Docker file does and the different pieces of it.

First off, we're using the `bullseye-slim` version of Node 18.

This is a very slimmed down base image for us that has Node pre-installed for us.

And then, we're going to use apt-get to get a couple of dependencies for Prisma, specifically OpenSSL and SQLite 3.

We're making another layer here for all of the dependencies, including dev dependencies.

Then we'll make another layer for our production dependencies only, which basically copies everything over from the deps that we just installed, but then prunes out everything that's the dev dependencies.

And this will be the dependencies we use for our running app.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815805/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-03-dockerfile.mp4/03-dockerfile_7_01-03280-so-ill-kind-of-walk-through-what-this-docker-file-does-and-the-different-pieces-of-it.png)

Then it's time to build the app.

So based on our base image, we're going to make a directory called `/app/`. We'll move into that directory, and then we'll copy all the dependencies from our dev dependencies layer.

Then we'll add to the Prisma directory so that when we run `prisma generate`, it'll have our Prisma schema. This will generate the Prisma client for us.

After that we'll add the rest of the code to our project so that we can build everything else.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815797/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-03-dockerfile.mp4/03-dockerfile_13_02-07400-and-then-well-add-in-the-prisma-directory-so-that-when-we-run-prisma-generate--itll-have-our-prisma-schema.png)

We have our final layer, where we specify some environment variables:

For our database URL, we're going to put that at `file:/app/data/sqlite.db`. The database URL is used by Prisma, which is looking for our database by that environment variable.

Our `PORT` is used by our application right here. It pulls that off of the port number, off of the environment variable.

The `NODE_ENV` variable will be `production` because we're running in a production environment. We want node to be in production mode.

Then we're going to move into the `/app/` directory and copy a bunch of stuff from our production deps.

We're only going to get the node modules from production, and then from our build layer, we're going to copy the Prisma client that was generated along with the build directory that is created when we run our build.

After that we'll add the rest of the files from our source project just to make sure we cover all of our bases and then run the `npm start` script.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815802/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-03-dockerfile.mp4/03-dockerfile_18_02-45480-and-then-our-port-is-used-by-our-application-right-here-it-pulls-that-off-of-the-port-number--off-of-the-environment-variable.png)

## The `npm start` Script

The `npm start` script runs `node start.js`.

Inside of `start.js` we have a very important step that runs before we actually start the application, which is to run:

```markdown
npx prisma migrate deploy
```

This command tells Prisma to look through the migrations and compare those with the database that's actually running. Then it will ensure to run all of the migrations in the running database are missing.

That's why we run the `prisma migrate deploy` command before we actually run node on the `build` directory where our files were built

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680817370/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-03-dockerfile.mp4/03-dockerfile_24_03-52440-.png)

And so that's what the npm start command does. And that's what we configure Docker to run when the image is ready, and we're running in a container.

## Testing Docker

To test all of this out and make sure it's working, we're going to run d`ocker build` on the current directory.

This will run everything in our Docker file.

Because this is the first time, it may take a little while. It has to install all of the apt-get dependencies. It's going to install our npm dependencies and follow the rest of the steps in the Dockerfile.

After a few moments, Docker is ready to go, and we can run `docker images` and see our Docker image.

To test it out, we will say `docker run` with `-p` to forward port 8080 along with the flags `i` and `t` and our pasted image id.

Here's what the command looks like all together (your image id will be different):

```markdown
docker run -p 8080:8080 -i -t 1fca1038c819
```

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815796/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-03-dockerfile.mp4/03-dockerfile_35_05-07400-and-that-gets-everything-running--we-can-go-to-port-8080-on-our-local-machine--and-this-is-being-passed-through-to-our-image.png)

Now we can open a browser window to localhost:8080 and see that our app is running through the image!

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815788/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-03-dockerfile.mp4/03-dockerfile_36_05-11800-and-we-can-see-that-our-app-is-indeed-working-and-running-through-that-image.png)

This image is now ready to deploy to Fly, and you can adjust it as needed for your application!

lessons.body:
With our Docker file ready, we can now deploy our app using Fly.

## Fly Deployment

Fly makes deploying Docker simple. To get started, run `fly launch`.

It will ask for an app name, which must be globally unique across Fly. You can enter a descriptive name or leave it blank for an autogenerated one.

Next, choose the region where you want to deploy your app. By default, it highlights the region closest to you. We will set up deployment to multiple regions later.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815817/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-04-fly-launch.mp4/04-fly-launch_7_00-45480-the-one-thats-closest-to-me--which-is-san-jose.png)

After creating the app, you can visit the admin URL to see it. Your app will be hosted at `your-app-name.fly.dev`.

Fly also writes a config file to `fly.toml` that contains our app name and other details. You can read more about it in their docs.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815804/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-04-fly-launch.mp4/04-fly-launch_13_01-03820-theres-our-app-name-weve-got.png)

During the setup process, Fly may ask if you want to set up Postgres or Redis. For this example, we'll skip both.

Finally, confirm that you want to deploy your app.

## Remote Builder

Fly sets up a special Remote Builder app in your account that is responsible for building Docker images remotely. This service is free and enables seamless integration with CI/CD tools like GitHub Actions.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815819/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-04-fly-launch.mp4/04-fly-launch_23_02-04680-so-we-dont-have-to-build-them-locally.png)

When you visit your app's dashboard, you'll be able to see the app your created as well as the builder app.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815804/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-04-fly-launch.mp4/04-fly-launch_28_02-27400-so-coming-back-to-this-.png)

Back in the terminal, Fly is uploading the image and witl be deploying it when it's finished.

## Useful Fly Commands

There are several useful `fly` commands to become familiar with.

`fly logs` displays logs for your app based on the `fly.toml `configuration file.

The `fly status` command shows the current status of your app. Adding `--watch` will continuously update the status.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815810/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-04-fly-launch.mp4/04-fly-launch_38_03-12320-and-this-will-stay-up-to-date-as-the-deployment-proceeds.png)

Once it's deployed, `fly open` Opens your app in a browser window.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815831/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-04-fly-launch.mp4/04-fly-launch_41_03-26480-if-we-look-at-the-logs-now-.png)

All we did was create a Dockerfile and say `fly launch` and then Fly took care of the rest!

lessons.title: Persist Application Data Between Deployments
lessons.body:
As of right now, incrementing and decrementing the counter works.

But when we make a change to add a `console.log` and redeploy, the counter is back to zero.

The count resets because we have not persisted the volume. Every time we deploy, the hard drive for our app is basically brand new.

In the deployment logs you can see that migrations have been applied, even though they shouldn't have been because they were applied the last time we deployed.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815818/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-05-persisted-volumes.mp4/05-persisted-volumes_14_01-21360-says-the-following-migrations-have-been-applied.png)

We will solve this problem by creating a persisted volume with Fly.

## Creating a Persisted Volume with Fly

Fly has built-in support for encrypted persisted volumes.

We'll create a 1 GB volume called `data` by running the following command:

```sh
fly vol create data --size 1
```

Select the region where your app is hosted when prompted, then wait for the volume to be created.

## Updating the Fly Configuration

Now we need to update the `fly.toml` file to specify that we have a newly created volume to mount.

We'll add the following under the `mounts` section:

```yaml
source = "data"
destination = "/data"
```

The `source` is the name of the volume we created earlier, and the `destination` is the desired path within the container. You can set it however you want, but I like to use `/data`.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815818/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-05-persisted-volumes.mp4/05-persisted-volumes_14_01-21360-says-the-following-migrations-have-been-applied.png)

## Updating the Dockerfile

Over in the Dockerfile, we need to modify the database URL to point to the new persisted volume by changing the database URL from `file:/app/data/sqlite.db` to `file:/data/sqlite.db`.

We're making this change because `/app/` is new every time but `/data` will be persisted.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815823/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-05-persisted-volumes.mp4/05-persisted-volumes_33_02-53200-to-stay-inside-of-this-special-hard-drive-that.png)

## Deploying the Changes

With the changes made, run `fly deploy` to update the app with the new configuration.

```sh
fly deploy
```

This will deploy the updated Docker configuration and `fly.toml` file, persisting the database between deploys.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815827/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-05-persisted-volumes.mp4/05-persisted-volumes_36_03-13840-and-so-well-test-that-out.png)

## Testing Persistence

After successfully deploying the updated configuration, refresh the app.

Increment the count a few times, then make a small change to the code, like removing the `console.log`, then deploy the app again using `fly deploy`.

Once the new deployment is complete, refresh the app and verify that the count remains the same, confirming that the persisted volume works as intended!

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815827/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-05-persisted-volumes.mp4/05-persisted-volumes_45_03-55880-and-all-that-we-had-to-do-was-say-fly-vol-create.png)

To recap, we created a persistent volume with Fly. We then updated the configurations in `fly.toml` and the `Dockerfile` allow the app's SQLite database to persist between deployments. This allows us to ensure the count doesn't reset to zero on each deploy.

lessons.title: Adding Deployment Health Checks
lessons.body:
Applications that you care about should be tested.

While we won't get into testing in this tutorial, Fly does feature health checks that can be thought of as a last line of defense when deploying an application.

## TCP Health Check

In our `fly.toml` file we can see that Fly already has a TCP health check in place.This ensures the application is ready to accept network connections, but it doesn't actually make a request to the application.

```yaml
[[services.tcp_checks]]
  grace_period = "1s"
  interval = "15s"
  restart_limit = 0
  timeout = "2s"
```

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815840/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-06-healthcheck.mp4/06-healthcheck_5_00-22040-called-a-tcp-check-which-will-just-make-sure-that-our-application-is-ready-to.png)

## Adding HTTP Health Checks

To further enhance our checks, we can add an HTTP check to make a request to the application and deploy it only if it responds with a 200 OK status.

Inside of the Fly.io docs is more information about `services.http_checks` along with a starter we will copy.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815841/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-06-healthcheck.mp4/06-healthcheck_11_01-16200-were-going-to-copy-this-and-bring-it-over-here-right-below-our.png)

Add the following lines below the TCP check in `fly.toml`:

```yaml
[[services.http_checks]]
interval = 10000
grace_period = "1s"
method = "get"
path = "/"
protocol = "http"
restart_limit = 0
timeout = 500
tls_skip_verify = false
```

This configuration will perform an HTTP GET request every 10 seconds. The grace period of 1 seconds is how long it waits to check after the application starts up. You might need to make this longer for larger apps.

The restart limit is set to 0, which means it won't automatically restart the server after failed HTTP checks. You might want to increase this in your own applications.

There is also the option to add HTTP headers to your checks.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815835/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-06-healthcheck.mp4/06-healthcheck_29_03-15560-you-want-to-make-authenticated-requests-or-something-like-that-you-can-add.png)

## Testing Health Checks

Let's do a `fly deploy` to test our health checks.

After deploying your application with the new HTTP health check, notice that 2 health checks ran and passed.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815835/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-06-healthcheck.mp4/06-healthcheck_36_03-57360-so-now-there-are-two-of-them-and-after-a-while-theyre-both-passing-so-if-we-go.png)

To test the health checks, you can deliberately introduce an error in your code and deploy the application.

For example, you can misspell "GET" in the `index.ts` application code and redeploy the app.

Fly will try to deploy the broken version, but since the HTTP health check fails the terminal shows us 1 passing, 1 critical:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815869/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-06-healthcheck.mp4/06-healthcheck_44_04-43600-all-right-so-now-we-see-that-we-do-still-have-those-two-health-checks-one-is.png)

Because the health check failed, Fly will roll back to the previously good deployment.

## Adding Custom Health Check Endpoints

You can add multiple health checks to further ensure that your application is working.

For example, we an create a custom health check endpoint that checks the database connection by making some queries.

Inside of `fly.toml` copy and paste the existing `services.http_checks` block and change the path to `/healthcheck`:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815838/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-06-healthcheck.mp4/06-healthcheck_67_07-19880-not-only-will-check-that-i-can-accept-traffic-on-my-home-page-but-also-will.png)

Then inside of `index.ts` we'll add a case to the `switch` statement for `GET /healthcheck` that will get the current count:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815845/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-06-healthcheck.mp4/06-healthcheck_73_08-12680-res-right-head-200-and-res-end-okay-so-were-all-set-there-and-so-now-we-have.png)

With this custom health check, we can verify not only that the application can accept traffic on the home page, but also that it can make queries to the database.

## Wrapping Up

Our application now has three health checks: the TCP health check, the HTTP health check for the home page, and the additional health check endpoint that checks the database connection.

Remember, health checks are not a replacement for tests but serve as a helpful last line of defense before deploying an application!

With a long-running node server and a database, sometimes it's useful to ssh into the virtual machine to explore the file system, and look at the database.

You can do that with Fly!

### Connecting to the Running Virtual Machine

To get a console into the running virtual machine, use the `fly ssh console` command.

Once connected, you can list the directories and files with `ls -al`.

The application is in the `/app` directory, and the SQLite database in the `/data`:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815846/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-07-ssh-sqlite-console.mp4/07-ssh-sqlite-console_6_00-31840-we-know-that-our-app-is-running-inside-of-app-.png)

### Running Bash and SQLite 3

Running the `bash` command gives us access to everything Bash can do. We can also interact with the database by running the `sqlite3` command and pointing it to our database:

```sh
sqlite3 /data/sqlite.db
```

You can view tables and execute database queries directly from there.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815844/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-07-ssh-sqlite-console.mp4/07-ssh-sqlite-console_16_01-24320-and-its-really-nice-to-be-able-to-do-that-.png)

### Simplifying Database Access with a Dockerfile Modification

It's useful to run these commands, but it does introduce some overhead every time we want to run them.

To make database access easier, we can add a command to the Dockerfile.

Inside of the Dockerfile where the environment variables are set, add this command:

```text
RUN echo '#!/bin/sh\nset -xe\nsqlite3 \$DATABASE_URL' > /usr/local/bin/database_cli && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/database_cli
```

This command will create a new file inside `user/local/bin/database_cli`. This file will contain a script that runs SQLite 3 on the database URL, and makes sure the script is executable.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815846/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-07-ssh-sqlite-console.mp4/07-ssh-sqlite-console_27_02-23840-and-then-we-make-sure-that-that-is-executable.png)

Save these changes, then push and redeploy the app.

### Testing the SQLite CLI Shortcut

After deploying the changes with `fly deploy`, you can use `fly ssh console -C database_cli` to jump straight into the SQLite CLI.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815851/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-07-ssh-sqlite-console.mp4/07-ssh-sqlite-console_33_02-58840-and-whatever-other-sql-commands-that-i-want-to.png)

Use this technique with discretion, but it's a convenient way to access your database using the simple echo command in the Dockerfile.

You can also adapt this for any other commands that you want to easily execute within your Docker VM running on Fly.

lessons.title: Configure GitHub Actions for Automatic Deployment
lessons.body:
Instead of having to run `fly deploy` manually every time we make changes, we can set up automatic deployment using GitHub Actions.

## Creating the GitHub Action Workflow

First, we need to create the GitHub Action Workflow.

Create a new `.github/` directory, then inside of it create a `workflows` directory.

Inside of `.github/workflows `create a new `deploy.yml` file.

### Configuring the `deploy.yaml`

In the `deploy.yaml`, we need to configure the following for the GitHub Action.

The action name will be `Deploy`, and it should only run on pushes to the main branch.

Under the `jobs` section we'll create a job called `deploy` that runs on `ubuntu-latest`. This job will have two steps: checking out the repo and then running the `deploy` command with Fly.

However, the deployment step isn't as simple as just running `fly deploy`.

First we'll have to install it, which we'll do with the `superfly/flyctl-actions` tool. This will allow us to run the deploy command with specific args of `--remote-only` so that the Fly builder runs it instead of the GitHub Action running it.

We'll also add an env variable for the Fly API Token. 

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815773/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-08-simple-github-deploy-action.mp4/08-simple-github-deploy-action_20_01-51840-that-would-not-be-a-good-thing.png)

All together, the `deploy.yaml` should look like this:

```yaml
name:  Deploy
on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  deploy:
    name:  Deploy
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name:  Checkout repo
        uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name:  Deploy Production
        uses: superfly/flyctl-actions@1.3
        with:
          args: "deploy --remote-only"
        env:
          FLY_API_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.FLY_API_TOKEN }}
```

## Setting Up the Fly API Token

In order to authenticate with Fly.io from within the GitHub Action, we need to create an API token and provide it to the action.

The first step is to visit your Fly.io dashboard, then go to `Account > Access Tokens`.

Create a new token called "GitHub Action", then copy it to your clipboard.



![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815775/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-08-simple-github-deploy-action.mp4/08-simple-github-deploy-action_22_02-08520-well-call-create--well-copy-that-.png)

Next, go to your GitHub repository settings and go to `Secrets and Variables > Actions`. 

Create a new repository secret called `FLY_API_TOKEN` to match the Action config, and paste in the copied token: 

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815850/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-08-simple-github-deploy-action.mp4/08-simple-github-deploy-action_25_02-33600-add-that-secret--and-now-were-ready-to-commit-this.png)

## Committing and Pushing the Workflow

Once we have set up the `deploy.yaml` and added the API token to our repo secrets, we can commit and push the changes.

After pushing the changes, when we go to the `Actions` tab of the repo we can see that Deploy is running:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815857/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-08-simple-github-deploy-action.mp4/08-simple-github-deploy-action_30_03-16200-and-now-its-going-to-push-that-image-up-to-fly-.png)

Once the action completes, we can check the Fly dashboard to ensure that the deployment was successful.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815778/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-08-simple-github-deploy-action.mp4/08-simple-github-deploy-action_32_03-30600-there-we-go--its-shutting-down-the-virtual-machine-.png)

Now any time the main branch changes, the app will be automatically deployed to Fly.io!

lessons.title: Add a Staging Environment
lessons.description: A staging environment is useful for play testing before pushing changes to production. This can be quickly set up with GitHub Actions and Fly
lessons.body:
As of now, every commit that goes into main is going to go to production.

However, it's nice to be able to play around in a staging environment based on a dev branch.

The first step is to add an entry for the `dev` branch inside of `deploy.yml`

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815779/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-09-staging-envrionment.mp4/09-staging-envrionment_9_00-35080-because-of-the-way-that-things-are-configured-down-here.png)

There will be more changes inside of `deploy.yml` later.

## Creating a Staging Environment

We need to create a new Fly app for the staging environment.

Use the same app name with `-staging` appended to the end:

```markdown
fly apps create weathered-morning-92-staging
```

Next we'll create a persistent volume for the SQLite database in the staging environment. We'll use a size of 1, then choose your region.

```markdown
fly vol create data --app [your-app-name]-staging --size 1
```

## Updating the GitHub Actions Workflow

Now we're ready to update the Deploy Production step to run only if the branch being pushed is `main`.

To do this we'll add an "if" line that checks the ref:

```yaml
if: ${{ github.ref == 'refs/heads/main' }}
```

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815782/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-09-staging-envrionment.mp4/09-staging-envrionment_21_01-38320-so-now--this-step-will-only-execute.png)

To create the staging version, we'll copy and paste the production version and make some changes so it runs when the `dev` branch is pushed to.

Add the `--app` flag with the staging app name:

```yaml
if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/dev'
```

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815784/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-09-staging-envrionment.mp4/09-staging-envrionment_26_01-58400-to-look-up-our-app-name-inside-of-the-fly-toml.png)

The tricky part now is that it's going to look up our app name from `fly.toml`, but we don't want to use our production app's name.

To avoid duplicating the app name, we will use the `SebRollen/toml-action@v1.0.2` action.

This will allow us to set our app name as a variable called `steps.app_name`.

Then we can update the deploy command to get the output value from the `fly.toml` file and add "-staging" to the end.

```yaml
deploy --remote-only ${{ steps.app_name.outputs.value }}-staging
```

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815783/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-09-staging-envrionment.mp4/09-staging-envrionment_42_03-00840-and-thats-going-to-get-the-value-of-the-app-property.png)

## Commit the Changes

Now we'll commit and push these changes to the main branch, which will deploy to the production environment.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815778/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-09-staging-envrionment.mp4/09-staging-envrionment_46_03-18440-well-push-that.png)

We should verify that only the deploy production step runs, and the staging step is skipped.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815778/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-09-staging-envrionment.mp4/09-staging-envrionment_52_03-41520-and-here-we-can-see-the-deploy-staging-step-got-skipped-.png)

## Test the Staging Environment

In order to test the staging environment, create a new `dev` branch, then make a change like adding "Staging" to the demo app's title.

After committing and pushing the dev branch to GitHub, we can check the GitHub Actions workflow and ensure that only the deploy staging step runs.

This is also confirmed by the Overview tab in the Fly.io dashboard:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815785/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-09-staging-envrionment.mp4/09-staging-envrionment_63_04-52640-open-that-up.png)

And our staging app domain shows our updated title as well:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815780/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-09-staging-envrionment.mp4/09-staging-envrionment_64_04-55360-and-our-staging-environment-is-looking-exactly-the-way.png)

Follow this process to create a staging deployment for any of your future apps!

lessons.title: Prepare for Multi-Region Data with LiteFS
lessons.body:
Fly.io has built-in support for distributed Postgres and Redis, but by using LiteFS we'll be able to use SQLite as well.

LiteFS depends on the Fuse package, which acts as a virtual file system.

This means that our SQLite database will be moved into this virtual file system, which is how our application will access it. Behind the scenes, Fuse and LiteFS will write the actual database to a separate directory. LiteFS will intercept the reads and writes that happen in the virtual file system, and propagate changes to read replicas all over the world.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815792/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-10-init-litefs.mp4/10-init-litefs_10_01-16200-move-our-sqlite-database-into-this-virtual-file-system.png)

## Adding Fuse to Our App

In our Dockerfile, we need to add Fuse as dependency by adding it to the `apt-get` line:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815795/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-10-init-litefs.mp4/10-init-litefs_14_01-47280-the-next-thing-that-it-wants-us-to-do.png)

We'll copy over the LiteFS binary, then create and add a litefs.yml file to our Dockerfile. This config file specifies the virtual file system directory and data directory.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680882321/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-10-init-litefs.mp4/mpv-shot0003.jpg)

Inside of the `litefs.yml` file, we add entries for a `fuse` directory and a `data` directory.

In order to avoid duplicating configuration across files, we can create a `LITEFS_DIR` environment variable in the Dockerfile:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815797/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-10-init-litefs.mp4/10-init-litefs_27_03-00720-to-access-our-data--this-database-url.png)

Then in the `litefs.yml` file we can point the `fuse` directory to our `LITEFS_DIR` variable and put our actual data at `/data/litefs`:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815787/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-10-init-litefs.mp4/10-init-litefs_37_03-58720-so-this-is-where-the-actual-database-will-exist.png)

## Lease Configuration

Now that Fuse and LiteFS are installed and configured, the last thing we need to do lease configuration for LiteFS. This is important because it determines the primary region in a distributed architecture. The primary region will be the only one that can write to the database all other regions are just read replicas.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815786/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-10-init-litefs.mp4/10-init-litefs_42_04-32520-and-when-that-region-writes-to-the-database-.png)

For now we'll use a static lease configuration just so we can make sure LiteFS is set up correctly.

## Updating the Start Script

Inside the Dockerfile we need to update the command to mount LiteFS before running the `npm start` command:

```markdown
CMD ["litefs", "mount", "--", "npm", "start.js"]
```

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815789/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-10-init-litefs.mp4/10-init-litefs_55_05-46520-and-with-that-all-configured--we-can-deploy-this-and-run.png)

Now we will commit our changes and push them to kick off a new deployment.

In the Fly Dashboard's logs we can see that LiteFS mounted and we have a static primary lease that will be ready to connect to clusters for read replicas.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815789/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-10-init-litefs.mp4/10-init-litefs_72_06-54800-so-we-specified-we-only-have-one-static-primary--and-this-is-it.png)

Our demo app has been redeployed, though we did clear our existing data in this process.

If you want to migrate to this architecture from an existing database, you'll want to make sure you make a backup of your existing database and import the old data into LiteFS.

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815796/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-10-init-litefs.mp4/10-init-litefs_82_08-13440-in-our-view--the-way-that-we-made-this-work.png)

lessons.body:
If you're moving an existing application over to LiteFS, you probably have some existing data in your SQLite database you don't want to lose.

The Fly.io Docs has information about the LiteFS Import Command:

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815799/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-11-importing-old-data.mp4/11-importing-old-data_10_00-39880-we-can-import-the-old-data-because-we-do-still-have-that-old-data.png)

Let's work this process using our Counter demo.

## SSH into the Virtual Machine

First, SSH into the virtual machine by running the following command:

```markdown
fly ssh console -C bash
```

This will create a secure tunnel between you and the virtual machine that's currently running.

Once connected, we can get a listing of the `/data` directory that we specified in `fly.toml`:

```markdown
ls -al /data
```

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815797/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-11-importing-old-data.mp4/11-importing-old-data_20_01-17520-thats-where-our-new-database-is-found-.png)

In this directory, you'll find the old SQLite database file `sqlite.db` as well as the newer `litefs` directory.

## Import Old Data to New Database

To import the data from the old SQLite database to the new LiteFS-backed database, we'll need some information from the `Dockerfile`.

We can see from the `LITEFS_DIR` and `DATABASE_URL` environment variables that our current db file is located at `/data/sqlite.db`.

So our command to import our old data will be:

```markdown
litefs import --name sqlite.db /data/sqlite.db
```

![](http://res.cloudinary.com/epic-web/image/upload/v1680815799/epicweb.dev/tutorials/deploy-web-applications/images-11-importing-old-data.mp4/11-importing-old-data_41_02-34080-now-if-i-come-over-here-and-i-hit-refresh-.png)

The import should only take a few milliseconds.

After the import is complete, refresh your application, and the old data should be restored!
